Issue:

## What I did
formalized the steps outlined in https://github.com/storybooks/storybook/issues/2890 adding it to the middleware and in the react CLI

now it looks like this when you throw an error in the react storybook ![woo](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35976578/35652079-21c097fe-06b0-11e8-8547-99f01abaccfc.png)

## How to test
just startup a new storybook project

Is this testable with jest or storyshots? not sure

Does this need a new example in the kitchen sink apps? not sure

Does this need an update to the documentation? probably not

If your answer is yes to any of these, please make sure to include it in your PR."},"comment":{"url":"https://api.github.com/repos/storybooks/storybook/issues/comments/363986372","html_url":"https://github.com/storybooks/storybook/pull/2900#issuecomment-363986372","issue_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/storybooks/storybook/issues/2900","id":363986372,"user":{"login":"sw-yx","id":6764957,"avatar_url":"https://avatars1.githubusercontent.com/u/6764957?v=4","gravatar_id":"","url":"https://api.github.com/users/sw-yx","html_url":"https://github.com/sw-yx","followers_url":"https://api.github.com/users/sw-yx/followers","following_url":"https://api.github.com/users/sw-yx/following{/other_user}","gists_url":"https://api.github.com/users/sw-yx/gists{/gist_id}","starred_url":"https://api.github.com/users/sw-yx/starred{/owner}{/repo}","subscriptions_url":"https://api.github.com/users/sw-yx/subscriptions","organizations_url":"https://api.github.com/users/sw-yx/orgs","repos_url":"https://api.github.com/users/sw-yx/repos","events_url":"https://api.github.com/users/sw-yx/events{/privacy}","received_events_url":"https://api.github.com/users/sw-yx/received_events","type":"User","site_admin":false},"created_at":"2018-02-08T02:54:11Z","updated_at":"2018-02-08T02:54:11Z","author_association":"NONE","body":"I tried to update my fork/my branch up to reflect all your moves but your git hook is giving me a ton of scary errors and not letting me merge the branches. now it looks like this when you throw an error in the react storybook ![woo](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35976578/35652079-21c097fe-06b0-11e8-8547-99f01abaccfc.png)

## How to test
just startup a new storybook project

Is this testable with jest or storyshots? not sure

Does this need a new example in the kitchen sink apps? not sure

Does this need an update to the documentation? probably not

If your answer is yes to any of these, please make sure to include it in your ## How to test
just startup a new storybook project

Is this testable with jest or storyshots? not sure

Does this need a new example in the kitchen sink apps? not sure

Does this need an update to the documentation? probably not

If your answer is yes to any of these, please make sure to include it in your ### Example Output from Failed Travis CI Build Step
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8136030/35767278-76d3f32c-08b7-11e8-95da-3f635ff6ca9d.png)

This is due to the fact that pushing from a CI step requires a URL in the form of 
```
https://<access_token>@github.com/<user_name>/<repo_name>.git
```
There are `gists` that document bash scripts which publish to GitHub from Travis ([here](https://gist.github.com/willprice/e07efd73fb7f13f917ea) and [here](https://gist.github.com/domenic/ec8b0fc8ab45f39403dd)) that use this formatted URL.

`storybook-to-ghpages` as part of a Travis CI build step results in an authentication error (#29).

### Example Output from Failed Travis CI Build Step
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8136030/35767278-76d3f32c-08b7-11e8-95da-3f635ff6ca9d.png)

This is due to the fact that pushing from a CI step requires a URL in the form of 
```
https://<access_token>@github.com/<user_name>/<repo_name>.git
```
There are `gists` that document bash scripts which publish to GitHub from Travis ([here](https://gist.github.com/willprice/e07efd73fb7f13f917ea) and [here](https://gist.github.com/domenic/ec8b0fc8ab45f39403dd)) that use this formatted URL.

the release candidate version of React 16 support on v3.3.0-alpha.0? Using React 16.0.0-rc.3, I am getting this react-modal error:

```
_processChildContext is not available in React 16+.

This likely means you have multiple copies of React and are
attempting to nest a React 15 tree inside a React 16 tree using
unstable_renderSubtreeIntoContainer, which isn't supported.

Try to make sure you have only one copy of React
(and ideally, switch to ReactDOM.createPortal).

## What I did

added `forceReRender` to the exports in `'@storybook/react'`

## How to test

Storyshots

Does this need a new example in the kitchen sink apps?

Yes

Does this need an update to the documentation?

Yes

## Acceptance criteria:

### Platforms
- [x] React
- [ ] React Native
- [x] Angular
- [x] Vue

### Functionality
- [x] Ability to re-render from in stories
- [ ] Ability to re-render from addons via channel

### Misc
- [x] Kitchen sink example (cra)
- [x] Screenshots

## Sceenshot
![force rerender](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4509692/34018542-4c925fea-e0f8-11e7-8bf4-221e8e64c96f.gif)


## Future possibility

Issue details

According to the documentation, it is possible to customize the webpack config used by Storybook like so: https://storybook.js.org/configurations/custom-webpack-config/#full-control-mode--default

### Steps to reproduce

* Create new storybook (React)
* Create `.storybook/webpack.config.js`
* Populate as per the documentation: https://storybook.js.org/configurations/custom-webpack-config/#full-control-mode--default e.g.:

```
const path = require('path');

module.exports = (baseConfig, env, defaultConfig) => {
  defaultConfig.module.rules.push({
    test: /\.png$/,
    include: path.resolve(__dirname, '../'),
    loader: require.resolve('ignore-loader')
  });

  return defaultConfig;
};
```

* `npm run storybook`
* Notice error message:

```
/Users/mholland/Documents/GitHub/pvc-core/webui/.storybook/webpack.config.js:4
  defaultConfig.module.rules.push({
               ^

TypeError: Cannot read property 'module' of undefined
```

Seems like the third parameter to the function is not supplied?

### Please specify which version of Storybook and optionally any affected addons that you're running

- `@storybook/react` 3.3.10

### Affected platforms 

- Mac OS X High Sierra
- Node 6.11.2
- NPM 3.10.10

notes","color":"fbca04","default":false},{"id":343576456,"url":"https://api.github.com/repos/storybooks/storybook/labels/feature%20request","name":"feature request","color":"9B58D8","default":false}],"state":"open","locked":false,"assignee":null,"assignees":[],"milestone":null,"comments":7,"created_at":"2018-02-05T00:14:53Z","updated_at":"2018-02-08T18:31:59Z","closed_at":null,"author_association":"NONE","body":"hello, loving Storybook so far!

I want to use the Notes add on to display code alongside my notes (aka without importing from a separate `.md` file) but this involves the use of backticks. If I were to do this in a template literal that would fail, and `withNotes` currently doesn't support github flavored markdown (which has tilde versions of the backticks for this purpose). so for example this doesnt render as a code block:

```js
storiesOf('Notes', module)
  .addWithJSX(
    'with a WithService wrapper',
    withNotes(`
This demonstrates usage of Notes together with a WithService HOC (that uses a child render prop)

~~~js
<WithService service={exampleService}>
  {(itemList, onChange) => <Notes items={itemList} onChange={onChange} />}
</WithService>
~~~
    `)(() => (
      <WithService service={exampleService}>
        {(itemList, onChange) => <Notes items={itemList} onChange={onChange} />}
      </WithService>
    ))
  );
```

beacuse the ~ tildes are not recognized.

This is because we dont really do much processing in the [Notes addon source](https://github.com/storybooks/storybook/blob/master/addons/notes/src/register.js). I would like to propose using [react-markings](https://github.com/Thinkmill/react-markings) to add a richer inline markdown experience to the Notes addon.

Happy to do a PR for this but is this something that you'd like?"},"comment":{"url":"https://api.github.com/repos/storybooks/storybook/issues/comments/364205690","html_url":"https://github.com/storybooks/storybook/issues/2916#issuecomment-364205690","issue_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/storybooks/storybook/issues/2916","id":364205690,"user":{"login":"Hypnosphi","id":6651625,"avatar_url":"https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/6651625?v=4","gravatar_id":"","url":"https://api.github.com/users/Hypnosphi","html_url":"https://github.com/Hypnosphi","followers_url":"https://api.github.com/users/Hypnosphi/followers","following_url":"https://api.github.com/users/Hypnosphi/following{/other_user}","gists_url":"https://api.github.com/users/Hypnosphi/gists{/gist_id}","starred_url":"https://api.github.com/users/Hypnosphi/starred{/owner}{/repo}","subscriptions_url":"https://api.github.com/users/Hypnosphi/subscriptions","organizations_url":"https://api.github.com/users/Hypnosphi/orgs","repos_url":"https://api.github.com/users/Hypnosphi/repos","events_url":"https://api.github.com/users/Hypnosphi/events{/privacy}","received_events_url":"https://api.github.com/users/Hypnosphi/received_events","type":"User","site_admin":false},"created_at":"2018-02-08T18:31:59Z","updated_at":"2018-02-08T18:31:59Z","author_association":"OWNER","body":"given that notes understand html, this looks like the way to go

`withMarkdownNotes` maybe?"}}

notes","color":"fbca04","default":false},{"id":343576456,"url":"https://api.github.com/repos/storybooks/storybook/labels/feature%20request","name":"feature request","color":"9B58D8","default":false}],"state":"open","locked":false,"assignee":null,"assignees":[],"milestone":null,"comments":8,"created_at":"2018-02-05T00:14:53Z","updated_at":"2018-02-08T19:03:17Z","closed_at":null,"author_association":"NONE","body":"hello, loving Storybook so far!

I want to use the Notes add on to display code alongside my notes (aka without importing from a separate `.md` file) but this involves the use of backticks. If I were to do this in a template literal that would fail, and `withNotes` currently doesn't support github flavored markdown (which has tilde versions of the backticks for this purpose). so for example this doesnt render as a code block:

```js
storiesOf('Notes', module)
  .addWithJSX(
    'with a WithService wrapper',
    withNotes(`
This demonstrates usage of Notes together with a WithService HOC (that uses a child render prop)

~~~js
<WithService service={exampleService}>
  {(itemList, onChange) => <Notes items={itemList} onChange={onChange} />}
</WithService>
~~~
    `)(() => (
      <WithService service={exampleService}>
        {(itemList, onChange) => <Notes items={itemList} onChange={onChange} />}
      </WithService>
    ))
  );
```

beacuse the ~ tildes are not recognized.

This is because we dont really do much processing in the [Notes addon source](https://github.com/storybooks/storybook/blob/master/addons/notes/src/register.js). I would like to propose using [react-markings](https://github.com/Thinkmill/react-markings) to add a richer inline markdown experience to the Notes addon.

Happy to do a PR for this but is this something that you'd like?"},"comment":{"url":"https://api.github.com/repos/storybooks/storybook/issues/comments/364214707","html_url":"https://github.com/storybooks/storybook/issues/2916#issuecomment-364214707","issue_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/storybooks/storybook/issues/2916","id":364214707,"user":{"login":"tsiq-swyx","id":35976578,"avatar_url":"https://avatars0.githubusercontent.com/u/35976578?v=4","gravatar_id":"","url":"https://api.github.com/users/tsiq-swyx","html_url":"https://github.com/tsiq-swyx","followers_url":"https://api.github.com/users/tsiq-swyx/followers","following_url":"https://api.github.com/users/tsiq-swyx/following{/other_user}","gists_url":"https://api.github.com/users/tsiq-swyx/gists{/gist_id}","starred_url":"https://api.github.com/users/tsiq-swyx/starred{/owner}{/repo}","subscriptions_url":"https://api.github.com/users/tsiq-swyx/subscriptions","organizations_url":"https://api.github.com/users/tsiq-swyx/orgs","repos_url":"https://api.github.com/users/tsiq-swyx/repos","events_url":"https://api.github.com/users/tsiq-swyx/events{/privacy}","received_events_url":"https://api.github.com/users/tsiq-swyx/received_events","type":"User","site_admin":false},"created_at":"2018-02-08T19:03:17Z","updated_at":"2018-02-08T19:03:17Z","author_association":"NONE","body":"done :)"}}

Issue details
Adding a nested angular component which one component depends on other where those other are in different modules. If I just use the tutorial angular examples, didn't work.

### Steps to reproduce


Adding a nested angular component which one component depends on other where those other are in different modules. If I just use the tutorial angular examples, didn't work.
 The same error can be seen in spec test in angular. And is fixed adding in declarations the component or adding into imports the module where the nested component exist ( the second solution only works if the nested component is declared in exports ngModule ).

https://ibb.co/dTXdU6

"},"comment":{"url":"https://api.github.com/repos/storybooks/storybook/issues/comments/364221107","html_url":"https://github.com/storybooks/storybook/issues/2691#issuecomment-364221107","issue_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/storybooks/storybook/issues/2691","id":364221107,"user":{"login":"sam-berry","id":4997059,"avatar_url":"https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/4997059?v=4","gravatar_id":"","url":"https://api.github.com/users/sam-berry","html_url":"https://github.com/sam-berry","followers_url":"https://api.github.com/users/sam-berry/followers","following_url":"https://api.github.com/users/sam-berry/following{/other_user}","gists_url":"https://api.github.com/users/sam-berry/gists{/gist_id}","starred_url":"https://api.github.com/users/sam-berry/starred{/owner}{/repo}","subscriptions_url":"https://api.github.com/users/sam-berry/subscriptions","organizations_url":"https://api.github.com/users/sam-berry/orgs","repos_url":"https://api.github.com/users/sam-berry/repos","events_url":"https://api.github.com/users/sam-berry/events{/privacy}","received_events_url":"https://api.github.com/users/sam-berry/received_events","type":"User","site_admin":false},"created_at":"2018-02-08T19:25:39Z","updated_at":"2018-02-08T19:25:39Z","author_association":"NONE","body":"@igor-dv I like the general idea of community-sourced documentation for sure, but I think it would be much better for individuals who are experienced with this framework to produce the first version of docs.

Storybook seems like an awesome tool and I'm hoping it can be something I can use to easily bridge the gap between design and implementation (for a project that has a designer who can create components). Immediately out of the gate I ran into the issue defined here though - trying to figure out how I can import an entire module for a component (Angular 5). 

Is there more in-depth API documentation somewhere for how to use the different options displayed in the example you pointed to? Specifically, `moduleMetadata` and `addDecorator`?

It is great that there are examples and I am confident I will be able to figure out what I need to from the code, but I agree with @amorenew that it would be very helpful to have some additional docs around how to do this specific thing at least. If users are following Angular best practice then they will almost certainly need to import an entire module.

If I have success with Storybook and move forward with it perhaps I will try to open up a PR for documentation, but like I said I think it would be much more efficient for someone who is already comfortable in this framework to fill in those few details."}}

Issue details

When using the [Storybook Centered Decorator](https://github.com/storybooks/storybook/tree/master/addons/centered) addon, it appears that it may be trying to center the component before the iframe has been rendered when using IE11. This causes the component top be rendered out of the viewport.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Configure Storybook with a global centered decorator in `config.js` 
2. Run Storybook in a virtual machine running IE11

### Please specify which version of Storybook and optionally any affected addons that you're running

- @storybook/react 3.2.18
- @storybook/addon-centered 3.2.18

### Affected platforms 

- IE11

Issue details

When using the [Storybook Centered Decorator](https://github.com/storybooks/storybook/tree/master/addons/centered) addon, it appears that it may be trying to center the component before the iframe has been rendered when using IE11. This causes the component top be rendered out of the viewport.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Configure Storybook with a global centered decorator in `config.js` 
2. Run Storybook in a virtual machine running IE11

### Please specify which version of Storybook and optionally any affected addons that you're running

- @storybook/react 3.2.18
- @storybook/addon-centered 3.2.18

### Affected platforms 

- IE11

### Screenshots / Screencast / Code Snippets (Optional)

## What I did

Added support for `.add(name, fn, { options })`, and similarly passing the options back as part of the story `context`.

### Notes

This PR is incomplete, I have another one with some tests for the storystore that I will augment this with. I am interested in feedback on the feature and the approach.

Note that the various app layers no longer call `.getStory()` (now deprecated I think) and instead call the wrapped `.getStoryWithContext()` that handles the (generic) task of setting a context for the story. I think I caught all the places where we do this but let me know if not. Also need to test properly for all 4 app layers.

### TODO

- [x] Add tests
- [ ] Add documentation
- [ ] Update addons to make use of it? Issue details

According to the documentation, it is possible to customize the webpack config used by Storybook like so: https://storybook.js.org/configurations/custom-webpack-config/#full-control-mode--default

### Steps to reproduce

* Create new storybook (React)
* Create `.storybook/webpack.config.js`
* Populate as per the documentation: https://storybook.js.org/configurations/custom-webpack-config/#full-control-mode--default e.g.:

```
const path = require('path');

module.exports = (baseConfig, env, defaultConfig) => {
  defaultConfig.module.rules.push({
    test: /\.png$/,
    include: path.resolve(__dirname, '../'),
    loader: require.resolve('ignore-loader')
  });

  return defaultConfig;
};
```

* `npm run storybook`
* Notice error message:

```
/Users/mholland/Documents/GitHub/pvc-core/webui/.storybook/webpack.config.js:4
  defaultConfig.module.rules.push({
               ^

TypeError: Cannot read property 'module' of undefined
```

Seems like the third parameter to the function is not supplied?

### Please specify which version of Storybook and optionally any affected addons that you're running

- `@storybook/react` 3.3.10

### Affected platforms 

- Mac OS X High Sierra
- Node 6.11.2
- NPM 3.10.10

I wanted to use addon-info to get props in stories, but I got something like this in PropTypes section:
"withTheme(withStyles(Avatar))" Component
No propTypes defined!

When I run 'npm run storybook' I get a lot of errors about unresolved symbols (which I don't get when I run the project on the app.

Follow the step in the slow setup documentation: https://storybook.js.org/basics/guide-react/

in the terminal type 'npm run storybook'

=> lots of error

I tried the solution outlined in https://github.com/storybooks/storybook/issues/1503 (run 'sudo npm run storybook'), but that did not work.

Issue details

When using the [Storybook Centered Decorator](https://github.com/storybooks/storybook/tree/master/addons/centered) addon, it appears that it may be trying to center the component before the iframe has been rendered when using IE11. This causes the component top be rendered out of the viewport.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Configure Storybook with a global centered decorator in `config.js` 
2. Run Storybook in a virtual machine running IE11

### Please specify which version of Storybook and optionally any affected addons that you're running

- @storybook/react 3.2.18
- @storybook/addon-centered 3.2.18

### Affected platforms 

- IE11

https://github.com/storybooks/storybook/issues/993

## What I did

Added support for `.add(name, fn, { options })`, and similarly passing the options back as part of the story `context`.

### Notes

This PR is incomplete, I have another one with some tests for the storystore that I will augment this with. I am interested in feedback on the feature and the approach.

Note that the various app layers no longer call `.getStory()` (now deprecated I think) and instead call the wrapped `.getStoryWithContext()` that handles the (generic) task of setting a context for the story. I think I caught all the places where we do this but let me know if not. Also need to test properly for all 4 app layers.

### TODO

- [x] Add tests
- [ ] Add documentation
- [ ] Update addons to make use of it?
